StoryContext.StorySummary: As a user, I want to access a comprehensive settings menu with categorized options and a search function, so that I can easily find and manage my app preferences.
StoryContext.FrontendContext: This is a frontend-focused story. It involves creating the main settings page, including navigation elements and a search component. A shared layout for all settings pages should be created to ensure a consistent look and feel.
StoryContext.BackendContext: No new backend development is required for this story. It's purely about client-side presentation and navigation.
StoryContext.DataContext: The list of settings categories can be hardcoded or dynamically loaded from a client-side configuration file for easy maintenance.
StoryContext.UXContext: The settings menu should be intuitive and follow common design patterns for navigation. The search functionality is a key usability feature that should provide real-time filtering of the settings categories.
StoryContext.Dependencies: - Story 1.2 (User Authentication): Requires a logged-in user to access the settings area.
StoryContext.Risks: - The settings structure might grow complex, making the navigation difficult to maintain. Mitigation: Design a scalable component structure for settings categories and sub-pages.
StoryContext.Assumptions: - The initial set of settings categories is defined and stable. - The UI/UX designs for the main settings menu (Flow 18, Screen 1) are finalized.
StoryContext.TechnicalNotes: - Implement a client-side search filter. - Use Next.js App Router for creating the settings routes (e.g., `/settings`, `/settings/appearance`). - Placeholder pages should be created for each category to ensure navigation works correctly.
